title: Force on piston during two processes

content.description: A sealed cylinder with a movable piston contains <math alttext="N" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules of an ideal gas. The gas is initially in the state with pressure <math alttext="P sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and volume <math alttext="3 V sub 0 " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> shown on the graph of pressure <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The gas is then taken through the two processes shown.
content.question: Which of the following claims correctly describes the average force the gas exerts on the piston as the gas is taken through one of the processes?

choices.label: The average force increases during process 1 because the volume of the gas decreases.
The average force decreases during process 1 because the temperature decreases.
The average force increases during process 2 because the pressure of the gas increases.
The average force remains the same during process 2 because the volume of the gas does not change.

content.answer: The average force increases during process 2 because the pressure of the gas increases.

topic.text: 9.1: Kinetic Theory of Temperature and Pressure

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
